title: How long does a creditor have to produce and collect on a bill after someone is deceased in the sate of California?
question: My mother died over a year ago. I was executor of her estate (about$300,000) via a living trust. I paid all bills as they came in, sold her home and filed her final tax return through a CPA. After waiting over 6 months for any additional bills I disbursed the remaining funds to the heirs (my siblings and myself). Today, over one year after her death, I received a letter from the care facility she was in stating that we have an overdue bill of $4,800.00. As I recall we paid the care facility in full shortly after her death. We have not received any bills before this one indicating any amount still due. Should I even acknowledge this bill by contesting it. It was sent to her so should I just mark it "deceased" and send it back, or ignore it all together?
answers:
It depends upon whether thee was a probate estate or a trust administration. In a probate estate (you say that you were "executor" of the estate), a Notice to Creditors is sent to all known creditors and is published. After publication the state is administered and then distributed. Such a probate distribution is free and clear of creditor claims. If there was no probate court proceeding, the distribution of the trust should have been done under the supervision of the attorney for the trust.

In a probate estate after the assets are distributed, and proper receipts filed, the court will enter an order ending the responsibilities of the executor. Under a trust, it will depend, in part, on the terms of the trust document and upon the facts of your situation. I suggest that you meet with a trust and estates lawyer to review the specifics of your situation before communicating with the creditor.

If you opened probate and followed all of the rules, you, as the executer, are free of any liability for the estate's unpaid debts. Best talk this over with the probate attorney who represented the estate.

Watch out for unpaid care facilities, as sometimes they get people to co-sign or guarantee any unpaid charges. If you have a final statement showing a zero balance at time of death, then you should consider disputing this bill. Writing "deceased" and sending it back is not a proper way to dispute that this was paid when your mother passed away. Sending a formal letter explaining that this was paid in full and indicating that the bill is disputed is more effective. Be sure to keep a copy of the letter and send it by U.S. Certified Mail, return receipt requested. You can also copy sample letter 1.1 on my sample letters, which I linked below.

Did you file a probate petition with the court or administer the decedent's trust? If so, then you would have sent notice to all potential creditors and obtained their proof of claim within the response period. Thereafter, all claims are cutoff and can be denied. If not, then the beneficiaries of the estate may be held liable for the decedent's unpaid debts. That is why people should consult and consider hiring a probate lawyer when a family member dies, even if they have few assets, because it closes the claim period on unpaid debts.
